{{BLP sources|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Domingos Quina | image = Quina London Stadium.jpg | image_size = | caption = Quina (right) coming on as a substitute for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in 2016 | fullname = Domingos Quina{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1999|11|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bissau]], [[Guinea-Bissau]] | height = 1.77 m | position = [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|Central midfielder]]
[[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] | clubnumber = 20 | youthyears1 = 2013 | youthclubs1 = [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] | youthyears2 = 2013–2016 | youthclubs2 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | youthyears3 = 2016–2018 | youthclubs3 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | years1 = 2016–2018 | clubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2018– | clubs2 = [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] | caps2 = 7 | goals2 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2015–2016 | nationalteam1 = [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 14 | nationalgoals1 = 8 | nationalyears2 = 2016 | nationalteam2 = [[Portugal national under-18 football team|Portugal U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 3 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2016– | nationalteam3 = [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 19 | nationalgoals3 = 3 | nationalyears4 = 2017– | nationalteam4 = [[Portugal national under-20 football team|Portugal U20]] | nationalcaps4 = 2 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | pcupdate = 08:49, 26 February 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 23 July 2018 }} '''Domingos Quina''' (born 18 November 1999) is a Portuguese [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]. Despite being born in [[Guinea-Bissau]], he has represented [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] at international youth level. He is the son of former Portugal international [[Defender (association football)|defender]] [[Samuel Quina]].{{cite web |url=https://www.ojogo.pt/internacional/noticias/interior/domingos-quina-assina-pelo-west-ham-5141895.html |title=Domingos Quina assina pelo West Ham |work=O Jogo |date=24 April 2016 |accessdate=9 August 2016}} ==Career== ===West Ham=== Having spent time at the academies of [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] and [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], he was offered a contract by [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]],{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10944712/west-hams-domingos-quina-wanted-by-arsenal|title=West Ham's Domingos Quina wanted by Arsenal|publisher=Sky Sports |date=11 July 2017 |accessdate=12 July 2018}} but Quina decided to sign for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in May 2016 with the expectation that he would join the squad in July 2016 and sign a professional contract on his 17th birthday in November 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/May/25-May/Hammers-sign-young-forward-Quina |title=Hammers sign young forward Quina |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=25 May 2016 |accessdate=21 November 2016}} He made his debut, coming on as an 81st-minute substitute for [[Michail Antonio]], against [[NK Domzale]] in the [[Europa League]] on 28 July 2016 and also played a part in the second leg in a 3–0 win in the club's first ever match at [[Olympic Stadium (London)|London Stadium]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36898501|title=NK Domzale 2–1 West Ham United|publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 July 2016|accessdate=9 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36964415|title=West Ham United 3-0 NK Domzale (agg 4-2)|publisher=BBC Sport| date=4 August 2016 |accessdate=9 August 2016}} On 3 October 2016, Quina scored a widely praised goal for [[West Ham United F.C. Under-23s and Academy|West Ham Under 23's]], by scoring a chip from near the halfway line against Leicester Under 23's side.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/west-hams-16-year-old-8969157|title=West Ham's 16-year-old wonderkid Domingos Quina beats keeper from 40 yards with sublime lob|publisher=Mirror|accessdate=12 July 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/116238 |title=Quina wonder goal gives West Ham winning start |publisher=Premier League |date=2 October 2016 |accessdate=16 July 2018}} Having turned 17, Quina signed his first professional contract with West Ham in November 2016 which could keep him at the club until 2019.{{Cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10666591/domingos-quina-signs-professional-terms-with-west-ham |title=Domingos Quina signs professional terms with West Ham |publisher=Sky Sports |date=21 November 2016 |accessdate=14 February 2018}} In the same year, he received two [[Candidate|nominations]] for [[Professional Development League|''Premier League 2'']] "''Player of the Month''" for October, merited for his performances against [[Aston Villa Under-23s and Academy|Aston Villa]], [[Middlesbrough F.C. Reserves and Academy|Middlesbrough]] and West Bromwich Albion respectively.{{Cite news|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/133149|title=PL2 Player of the Month nominees announced|last=|first=|date=4 November 2016|accessdate=18 December 2016|publisher=Premier League}} His performances for [[West Ham United F.C. Under-23s and Academy|West Ham Under 23's]] saw [[Sky Sports]] describe Quina as a '[[Child prodigy|wonderkid]]'. ===Watford=== On 9 August 2018, Quina signed for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on a four-year contract for a undisclosed fee, believed to be £1 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11686/11467431/domingos-quina-joins-watford-from-west-ham-on-four-year-deal|title=Domingos Quina joins Watford from West Ham on four-year deal|publisher=Sky Sports |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=5 December 2018}}{{cite news |title=Watford 'complete £1million deal' for West Ham wonderkid Domingos Quina - here's what we know |url=https://www.football.london/watford-fc/transfer-news/watford-domingos-quina-west-ham-15011545 |accessdate=1 November 2018 |work=football.london |date=9 August 2018}} He made his Watford debut on 29 August in a second round [[EFL Cup]] game away to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]. With Watford already leading 1–0, Quina scored with a driving shot, described as "superb", from 30 yards to make to score 2–0, the final result.{{Cite web |title=Reading 0–2 Watford: Domingos Quina scores as Javi Gracia's side keep up 100% start |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 August 2018 |accessdate=29 December 2018 |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45266832}} He made his [[Premier League]] debut for the club on 4 December 2018 coming as a substitute in a 2–1 home loss against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]{{cite web|url=https://maisfutebol.iol.pt/premier-league/inglaterra/bernardo-silva-sofre-para-vencer-watford-de-domingos-quina|title=Bernardo Silva sofre para vencer Watford de Domingos Quina|website=Maisfutebol |date=4 December 2018 |accessdate=5 December 2018}} and his first league start in the following match, on 10 December 2018, in a 2–2 away draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].{{Cite web |title=Everton 2–2 Watford: Lucas Digne's late free-kick rescues point for hosts |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 December 2018 |accessdate=29 December 2018 |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46422266}} On 15 December, he became the youngest Watford player to score in the Premier League, in a match against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].{{Cite web |title=Watford 3–2 Cardiff City |first=Katie |last=Falkingham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 December 2018 |accessdate=18 December 2018 |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46491892}} ==International career== Quina has represented Portugal at [[Portugal national under-17 football team|U17]], [[Portugal national under-18 football team|U18]], [[Portugal national under-19 football team|U19]] and [[Portugal national under-20 football team|U20]] level and is eligible to play for the country having moved there as a young child. He won the [[UEFA European Under-17 Championship]] with Portugal in May 2016.{{cite web |url=http://portugoal.net/selecao/451-portugal-crowned-u17-champions-of-europe |title=Portugal crowned U17 Champions of Europe! |first=Tom |last=Kundert |work=PortuGOAL.net |date=21 May 2016 |accessdate=9 August 2016}} In July 2018, he was a member of the [[Portugal national under-19 football team|U19]] team which won the [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] beating [[Italy national under-19 football team|Italy U19]] 4-3 after extra time.{{cite web |url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2018/july/29-july/quina-becomes-european-champion-second-time |title=Quina becomes European champion for a second time! |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=29 July 2018 |accessdate=5 December 2018}}{{Cite web | title = Italy 3-4 Portugal| publisher = UEFA|language=English| date = 30 July 2018| accessdate = 30 July 2018| url = https://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2018/matches/round=2000839/match=2024510/index.html}} {{Cite web |title=Domingos Quina, Moise Kean, Joao Filipe impress at Under-19 Euros |publisher=Sky Sports |date=30 July 2018 |accessdate=30 July 2018 |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/11454150/domingos-quina-moise-kean-joao-filipe-impress-at-under-19-euros}} ==Honours== ===International=== '''Portugal U17''' *[[UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]: [[2016 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|2016]] '''Portugal U19''' *[[UEFA European Under-19 Championship]]: [[2018 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2018]]{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2018/matches/round=2000839/match=2024510/index.html/|title=Under-19 - Portugal win epic U19 EURO final|publisher=[[UEFA]]|accessdate=30 July 2018}} ===Individual=== *[[2016 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|2016 UEFA European Under-17 Championship Team of the Tournament]]{{cite web|title=Technical Reportfinals|url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2016/technical-report/tr-under17-2016.pdf|publisher=UEFA.com|accessdate=24 October 2016}} *[[2018 UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Team of the Tournament|UEFA European Under-19 Championship Team of the Tournament]]: [[2018 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2018]]{{cite web|title=Under-19 EURO team of the tournament|url=https://www.uefa.com/under19/news/newsid=2565932.html|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=4 August 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 22 February 2019}} {| class=wikitable style="text-align: center;" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[Football League Cup|League Cup]] !colspan=2|[[UEFA#Club|Europe]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=3|[[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] |[[2016–17 West Ham United F.C. season|2016–17]]{{soccerbase season|id=96153|season=2016|accessdate=30 December 2018}} |rowspan=2|[[Premier League]] |0||0||0||0||0||0||2Appearances in [[UEFA Europa League]]||0|| colspan="2" |—||2||0 |- |[[2017–18 West Ham United F.C. season|2017–18]]{{soccerbase season|id=96153|season=2017|accessdate=30 December 2018}} |0||0||1||0||3||0|| colspan="2" |—|| colspan="2" |—||4||0 |- !colspan="2"|Total !0!!0!!1!!0!!3!!0!!2!!0!!0!!0!!6!!0 |- | rowspan="3" |[[West Ham United F.C. nationalyears3 = 2011 | nationalteam3 = [[Spain national under-20 football team|Spain U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 09:03, 20 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Francisco 'Kiko' Femenía Far''' ({{IPA-es|fɾanˈθisko femeˈni.a ˈfaɾ}}; born 2 February 1991) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].
==Club career== ===Hércules=== Born in [[Sanet y Negrals]], [[Province of Alicante|Alicante]], [[Valencian Community]], Femenía was a product of [[Hércules CF]]'s youth ranks. He made his first-team debut on 15 June 2008 at just 17, appearing in a [[Segunda División]] match at [[Cádiz CF]], a 1–1 draw which eventually certified the [[Andalusia]]ns' [[2007–08 Segunda División|relegation]] even though they protested against the illegal fielding of an opposing player, specifically the youngster.<ref>[https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/futbol/confirmado-el-descenso-del-cadiz-a-segunda-b-5821759 Confirmado el descenso del Cádiz a Segunda B (Cádiz's relegation to ''Segunda B'' confirmed)]; [[Sport (Spanish newspaper)|Sport]], 4 July 2008 (in Spanish)</ref>
During the [[2008–09 Segunda División|2008–09 season]], Femenía played another game with the main squad, again in the last round but against [[UD Salamanca]] (5–1 away win).<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2009/06/20/futbol/2adivision/1245525955.html El Hércules se despide a lo grande (Hércules say goodbye in style)]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 20 June 2009 (in Spanish)</ref> In the subsequent off-season, he signed his first professional contract after penning a five-year link<ref>[http://www.laverdad.es/alicante/20090812/deportes_alicante/hercules/kiko-firmara-contrato-profesional-20090812.html Kiko firmará un contrato profesional por cinco temporadas con el Hércules (Kiko will sign five-year professional contract with Hércules)]; [[La Verdad (Murcia)|La Verdad]], 12 August 2009 (in Spanish)</ref> and, in [[2009–10 Segunda División|the following campaign]], still only 18, he would be a much more important midfield unit, being the first [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for veteran [[Francisco Rufete]] and appearing in nearly 1,000 minutes in the league to help the club return to [[La Liga]] after an absence of 13 years.
On 28 August 2010, Femenía made his debut in the top division, replacing [[Abel Aguilar]] in the second half of the home fixture against [[Athletic Bilbao]]: after only a few minutes on the pitch, however, and a couple of poor decisions, he suffered an [[Panic attack|anxiety attack]] from which he later fully recovered, although the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basques]] eventually won it 1–0.<ref>[http://elhercules.com/actualidad/59341-kiko-femenia-derrota-a-la-ansiedad Kiko Femenía derrota a la anxiedad (Kiko Femenía defeats anxiety)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100907004503/http://elhercules.com/actualidad/59341-kiko-femenia-derrota-a-la-ansiedad|date=7 September 2010}}; El Hércules, 31 August 2010 (in Spanish)</ref>
===Barcelona=== Femenía joined [[FC Barcelona B]] on 6 July 2011, for [[Euro|€]]2 million plus €1.5 million in add-ons.<ref>[http://www.fcbarcelona.cat/web/castellano/noticies/futbol_b/temporada11-12/07/06/n110706118298.html Kiko Femenía se incorpora al Barça B (Kiko Femenía joins Barça B)]{{Dead link|date=September 2018|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}; FC Barcelona, 6 July 2011 (in Spanish)</ref> He scored his first official goal for his new team on 4 September, opening the score in a 4–0 away win against [[FC Cartagena]].<ref>[http://www.fcbarcelona.cat/web/castellano/noticies/futbol_b/temporada11-12/09/04/n110904119055.html Exhibición del filial en Cartagena (0–4) (B-team power display in Cartagena (0–4))]{{Dead link|date=September 2018|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}; FC Barcelona, 4 September 2011 (in Spanish)</ref>
Femenía netted five times in 30 games – 23 starts – in [[2011–12 Segunda División|his first season]], helping the [[Catalonia|Catalans]] to the eighth position.
===Real Madrid=== In late August 2013, Femenía was released by Barcelona, stating that he had been "ruined emotionally".<ref>[http://espnfc.com/news/story/_/id/1537132/kiko-femenia-slams-barcelona-leaves-real-madrid?cc=5739 Madrid-bound Femenia slams Barcelona]; [[ESPN FC]], 29 August 2013</ref> Just hours later, he signed for [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], being assigned to [[Real Madrid Castilla|the reserves]] in the second level.<ref>[https://archive.is/20130912114103/http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/ActualidadCantera1314_en/News/1193040523950/1330157928677/noticia/Noticia/Kiko_Femenia,_new_Castilla_player.htm Kiko Femenia, new Castilla player]; Real Madrid C.F, 28 August 2013</ref>
Femenía appeared in only five matches during [[2013–14 Segunda División|the whole campaign]], which ended in relegation, and left the club in December 2014.
===Alcorcón=== On 7 January 2015, Femenía signed a six-month deal with [[AD Alcorcón]] also in the second tier.<ref>[http://adalcorcon.com/kiko-femenia-nuevo-futbolista-de-la-a-d-alcorcon/ Kiko Femenía, nuevo futbolista de la A.D. Alcorcón (Kiko Femenía, new footballer of A.D. Alcorcón)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111013939/http://adalcorcon.com/kiko-femenia-nuevo-futbolista-de-la-a-d-alcorcon/|date=11 January 2015}}; AD Alcorcón, 7 January 2015 (in Spanish)</ref> He totalled 996 minutes of action during [[2014–15 Segunda División|the season]], helping his team finish 11th.
===Alavés=== On 2 July 2015, Femenía moved to fellow league side [[Deportivo Alavés]] after agreeing to a one-year contract.<ref>[http://www.deportivoalaves.com/el-deportivo-alaves-cierra-el-fichaje-de-kiko-femenia/ El Deportivo Alavés cierra el fichaje de Kiko Femenía (Deportivo Alavés complete the signing of Kiko Femenía)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702162556/http://www.deportivoalaves.com/el-deportivo-alaves-cierra-el-fichaje-de-kiko-femenia/|date=2 July 2015}}; Deportivo Alavés, 2 July 2015 (in Spanish)</ref> He contributed with 38 appearances and five goals in [[2015–16 Segunda División|his debut campaign]] as they returned to the top flight after ten years, and was eventually reconverted into a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]].<ref>[http://deportes.elpais.com/deportes/2016/05/29/actualidad/1464551891_854403.html El Alavés vuelve a Primera (Alavés return to ''Primera'')]; [[El País]], 29 May 2016 (in Spanish)</ref><ref>[https://www.vavel.com/es/futbol/alaves/680016-deportivo-alaves-1617-kiko-femenia.html Deportivo Alavés 2016/2017: Kiko Femenía (2016/2017 Deportivo Alavés: Kiko Femenía)]; [[Vavel]], 18 August 2016 (in Spanish)</ref>
Femenía left the club on 6 June 2017, as his contract was due to expire.<ref>[http://www.deportivoalaves.com/noticia/gracias-kiko-por-estas-2-temporadas-gloriosas Gracias Kiko por estas 2 temporadas Gloriosas (Thanks Kiko for these 2 Glorious seasons)]; Deportivo Alavés, 6 June 2017 (in Spanish)</ref>
===Watford=== On 1 July 2017, Femenía signed for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] after agreeing to a four-year deal.<ref>[https://www.watfordfc.com/teams/first-team/official-femenia-joins-hornets Official: Femenía joins Hornets]; Watford FC, 1 July 2017</ref> He made his debut in the [[Premier League]] on 12 August, coming on for injured [[Daryl Janmaat]] early into a 3–3 home draw against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/08/12/watford-vs-liverpool-premier-league-live-score-updates-team/ Watford 3 Liverpool 3: Miguel Britos scrambles home controversial injury-time equaliser in six-goal thriller]; [[The Daily Telegraph]], 12 August 2017</ref>
Femenía scored his first league goal for the English club on 31 March 2018, helping the hosts earn one point after a 2–2 home draw to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/mar/31/watford-bournemouth-premier-league-match-report Jermain Defoe rescues late point for Bournemouth at Watford]; [[The Guardian]], 31 March 2018</ref>

Roma|Roma]] | caps5 = 24 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2015– | clubs6= [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] | caps6 = 96 | goals6 = 6 | nationalyears1 = 2011–2016 | nationalteam1 = [[Greece national football team|Greece]] | nationalcaps1 = 38 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | club-update = 22:13, 3 March 2019 (UTC). | nationalteam-update = }} '''José Lloyd Cholevas''' ({{lang-el|Χοσέ Λόιντ Χολέβας}}; born 27 June 1984), known as '''José Holebas''' {{IPA-el|xoˈse xoˈlevas|}}, is a Greek professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left back]] or a [[Midfielder#Wide midfielder|left midfielder]] for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]. He played for the [[Greece national football team|Greek national team]] from 2011 to 2016.
==Early life== Holebas was born in [[Aschaffenburg]], [[Bavaria]], West Germany, to a [[Greeks|Greek]] father, Achilles, from [[Trikala]], and a [[Uruguay]]an mother, Lowis.
==Personal life== At the age of 18, Holebas became father to daughter Tanisha.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.bild.de/sport/fussball/loewen-chance-3490728.bild.html | title = Holebas: Löwen sind die Chance meines Lebens! | trans-title = Holebas: "Lions are the chance of my life" | language = German | publisher = [[Bild]] | accessdate = 7 January 2015| date = 16 January 2008}}</ref> In 2011, Holebas married Diana Jäger, a German woman who also hails from Aschaffenburg. Holebas speaks German and English fluently and although he does not speak much [[Greek language|Greek]], he understands it.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.main-netz.de/nachrichten/region/aschaffenburg/aschaffenburg-stadt/berichte/art4011,1658747 | title = Erst der Titel in Griechenland, dann die Hochzeit in der Heimat | trans-title = First the championship in Greece, then the wedding at home | language = German | publisher = Main-Netz.de | accessdate = 7 January 2015| date = 24 May 2011}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early years=== Holebas' first club was local youth team Südring, which he joined in 1992 when he was eight. He played at non-professional youth football teams in German football which included playing for Südring, FC Kleinwallstadt and TSV Teutonia Obernau until 2001, when his girlfriend got pregnant and José, at age 18, decided to temporarily give up football. He had to work the double shift as a warehouse assistant in order to financially support his family. A year later, in 2002 and with the guidance of his Uruguayan uncle, Alfonso, whom Holebas described as his "second father" and "who gave me the kicks I needed to get my life back on track," helped him begin playing football again. He played for local youth side Aschaffenburg-Damm from 2002 to 2005.<ref name="pineza.gr">{{cite web | url = http://www.pineza.gr/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=2908:ena-afierwma-sthn-apisteuth-zwi-tou-xose-xolempas&Itemid=210 | title = Ένα αφιέρωμα στην απίστευτη ζωή του Χοσέ Χολέμπας | publisher = pineza.gr| date = 20 October 2011}}</ref>
===Viktoria Kahl=== In 2005, Holebas was signed by German 6th-tier [[Landesliga Bayern-Nordwest]] club [[:de:FC Viktoria Kahl|FC Viktoria Kahl]]. Under manager Antonio Abbruzzese, he played as a striker and scored 15 goals in 33 appearances and finished among Landesliga's top scorers. [[TSV 1860 Munich|1860 Munich]] scouts approached him and Holebas joined their club in the summer of 2006.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thetoc.gr/athlitika/article/xose-xolebas-to-agori-me-ta-tatouaz| title = Χοσέ Χολέβας: Το αγόρι με τα τατουάζ| publisher = thetoc.gr| accessdate = 30 June 2014}}</ref>
===1860 Munich=== [[File:Jose Holebas 1860 2009.JPG|thumb|left|150 px|Holebas training with 1860 Munich in 2009]] In his first season in [[Munich]], Holebas was in 1860's [[TSV 1860 Munich II|second team]], where, at 22 years of age, he was considered "too old" by the club's youth academy coach, Ernst Tanner. Holebas officially made his debut for 1860 Munich II on 5 August 2006 in a [[Regionalliga Süd (1994–2012)|Regionalliga Süd]] game against [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim|1899 Hoffenheim]]. A year later, in the summer of 2007, Holebas signed his first professional contract with the [[TSV 1860 Munich|first team]]. He made his professional debut for the "Munich Lions" on 21 September 2007 at 23 years of age against [[FC St. Pauli|St. Pauli]], in a [[2. Bundesliga]] game.
Holebas accumulated three years of professional football experience in the German second tier with 1860 Munich, with the side finishing 11th in 2007–08, 12th in 2008–09 (while also dropping back to 1860 Munich II for a number of games) and 8th in 2009–10. In the summer of 2009, new coach [[Ewald Lienen]], advised 25-year-old Holebas to stay back and play as a defending left-winger.
Holebas finished his five-season stint in Germany with both Viktoria Kahl and 1860 Munich, scoring a total of 34 goals in 154 games in all competitions. Despite initially disliking the club as a child due to being a childhood fan of 1860's fierce cross-city [[Munich derby|Munich rivals]] [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern]], Holebas stated his changed opinion of the club that gave him his breakthrough in professional football, stating, "I'll forever be grateful to 1860 Munich."<ref name="pineza.gr"/>
===Olympiacos=== ====2010–11 season==== Ewald Lienen left 1860 Munich to become the coach of [[Superleague Greece]] club [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]]. Lienen signed Holebas for a transfer fee of €500,000. Holebas stated in an interview, "My father is Greek, but this is only the second time that I have come back to the country. When I was [here] first here, I was very young and do not remember many things, but I must say that I am very happy to play in the old country."
On 15 July 2010, Holebas made his debut for Olympiacos in a 5–0 away victory over [[Albania]]n club [[Besa Kavajë]] in the first leg of a [[2010–11 UEFA Europa League|Europa League second qualifying round]] tie. On 5 August, Olympiacos were knocked out of the [[UEFA Europa League]] by Israeli club [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]], on the [[away goals rule]] and after a 2–2 draw. Olympiacos sacked Lienen; the new coach, [[Ernesto Valverde]], began to use Holebas both as a defending and an attacking left winger, depending on Olympiacos' opponent. Holebas scored his first goal for the club on 20 March 2011 in a 6–0 home league win over [[AEK Athens F.C.|AEK Athens]], which sealed the club's 38th Greek championship title.
====2011–12 season==== On 19 October 2011, Holebas opened the score with a header against [[Borussia Dortmund]] in a 3–1 home victory on matchday 3 of the [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League group stage|Champions League group stage]]. On 3 March 2012, Holebas scored his second goal of the season in a 2–0 away league victory over [[OFI Crete F.C.|OFI Crete]], a goal that won the Superleague goal of the week award.<ref>[http://www.sport-fm.gr/videos/1024134 OΦΗ-Ολυμπιακός 0–2]</ref>
On 11 March, the next week, Holebas scored Olympiacos' second goal from the penalty spot in a 3–0 league away win over [[Aris Thessaloniki F.C.|Aris]]. Olympiacos went on to retain their league title for their second season in a row, winning their 39th Greek Championship title. On 28 April, Holebas started the [[2011–12 Greek Football Cup|Greek Cup Final]] against [[Atromitos F.C.|Atromitos]], where he missed a penalty kick in the first-half. Nonetheless, Olympiacos went on to win the Cup 2–1 after extra time, at the [[Spiros Louis Olympic Stadium|Athens Olympic Stadium]]. Holebas in the [[2011–12 Olympiacos F.C. season|2011–12 season]] scored 3 goals in 35 games in all competitions.
====2012–13 season==== On 23 September 2012, Holebas netted his first goal of the season by scoring Olympiacos' second goal in a 4–1 home league win over [[Panthrakikos F.C.|Panthrakikos]]. On 7 October, Holebas scored his second goal of the season by netting Olympiacos' first and only goal of the game in a 1–0 league home win over [[Asteras Tripoli F.C.|Asteras Tripoli]]. The next week, Holebas scored his third goal of the season by scoring the second goal in a 4–0 home league win over [[Skoda Xanthi F.C.|Skoda Xanthi]]. On 29 October, Holebas scored his fourth goal of the season by scoring Olympiacos' second goal and second equalizer in a 2–2 away league draw against Aris. Olympiacos went on to retain their league title for a third season in a row, their 40th Greek Championship title.
On 11 May 2013, Holebas started and played in the Greek Cup final, where Olympiacos went on to retain the cup for a second season in a row with a 3–1 victory after extra time over Asteras Tripoli with goals from [[David Fuster]], Rafik Djebbour and [[Djamel Abdoun]] at the Athens Olympic Stadium.<ref>[http://www.tovima.gr/sports/article/?aid=512253 Το κύπελλο στον Ολυμπιακό, οργή στον Αστέρα για τη διαιτησία]</ref> Holebas the [[2012–13 Olympiacos F.C. season|2012–13 season]] scoring four goals in 40 games in all competitions, winning another league and cup double.
====2013–14 season==== In the summer of 2013, there were rumours that Holebas would join Turkish club [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]], according to the Turkish media, which reported that he had agreed to sign a deal with the Black Eagles. The Turks reportedly offered the 29-year-old defender a three-year contract, with an annual salary reaching €750,000, a significant pay rise than what he was being paid by Olympiacos. The deal, however, was not completed, and Holebas decided to stay in Piraeus, subsequently signing a contract extension lasting until 2017.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://eu.greekreporter.com/2013/08/09/holebas-from-olympiacos-to-besiktas/ | title = Holebas From Olympiacos To Besiktas?| publisher = greekreporter.com| date = 9 August 2013}}</ref>
On 27 October 2013, Holebas scored his first goal of the season by netting Olympiacos's third goal with a wonderful free-kick in a 5–1 league home win over OFI Crete. On 18 January 2014, he scored his second goal of the season by netting their second goal in a 2–0 home league win over [[Levadiakos F.C.|Levadiakos]]. Olympiacos went on to retain their league title again for a fourth season in a row by winning their 41st Greek championship. He finished the [[2013–14 Olympiacos F.C. season|2013–14 campaign]] scoring two goals in 29 games in all competitions and winning another League title.
Holebas finished his very successful four-season stint with Olympiacos by netting ten toal goals in 135 games in all competitions, and also by winning the Superleague Greece four times in 2010–11, 2011–12, 2012–13 and 2013–14; the Greek Cup twice and in a row in 2011–12 and 2012–13; and participating in both the Champions League and Europa League.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sud.worldfootball.net/spieler_profil/jose-holebas/ | title = José Holebas | publisher = worldfootball.net | accessdate = 1 July 2012}}</ref>
===Roma===
On 30 August 2014, Holebas joined [[Serie A]] club [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] for a €1 million transfer fee from Olympiacos, plus €500,000 in bonuses. He signed a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.goal.com/en/news/11/transfer-zone/2014/08/31/5072331/roma-sign-jose-holebas|title =Roma sign Jose Holebas|publisher=www.goal.com|accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref> After being presented to the media in [[Rome]] by Roma [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Italo Zanzi]], Holebas stated why he joined Roma in a press conference: "I had other offers, but I decided on Roma because they are a great club at a European level. Was I expecting this move? I had discussions, it was a difficult situation because I was at the World Cup, but I am happy to be here because this is a great club. My preferred position? Certainly I will do my best. I am a left-back, playing in an attacking manner. I can also play at centre-back, but the Coach will decide."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.football-italia.net/55152/official-roma-sign-holebas|title =Official: Roma sign Holebas|publisher=football-italia.net|accessdate=6 September 2014}}</ref>
On 24 September 2014, Holebas made his debut for the club, by playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–1 away league victory over [[Parma F.C.|Parma]] in their fourth match of the [[2014–15 Serie A]].<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29311571|title =Parma 1- Roma 2 |publisher=www.bbc.com|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> On 30 November, Holebas scored his first goal for Roma in an important 4–2 home victory over [[Inter Milan|Internazionale]] in their 13th match of Serie A to stay in touch with the top of the table. He finished his [[2014–15 A.S. Roma season|2014–15 season]] scoring one goal in 34 games in all competitions, whilst keeping veteran English international left back [[Ashley Cole]] out of the team for much of the season. For the second season in a row, Roma finished runners-up to league champions [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], marking for the first time since the 2009–10 season that Holebas did not win any piece of silverware.
====Transfer speculation and controversy==== On 25 June 2015, it was reported that recently promoted [[Premier League]] club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] were close to securing a deal for Holebas after the side confirmed interest by contacting the Italians and admiring the player's profile; they allegedly offered between €2–3 million for his services. At that point, there was a summit at Trigoria between Roma Sporting Director [[Walter Sabatini]] and the entire staff, including head coach [[Rudi Garcia]] and Simone Beccaccioli. Talks between the two clubs continued, where it was growing likely that the deal would officially be announced the following Monday. Fabio Parisi, Holebas' agent, spoke to VoceGiallorossa about the situation: "Nothing is done. There is confirmation of Watford’s interest, but there is absolutely nothing done. For now, the player's will is to have a holiday."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://romapress.us/2015/06/26/sky-italia-holebas-a-step-away-from-watford-move/|title=Sky Italia: Holebas a step away from Watford move|publisher=romapress.us|date=25 June 2015}}</ref> On 2 July, Watford officially announced the signing of the Greek international from Roma, which Holebas denied when he found out 24 hours later after the announcement, claiming he did not know anything about it. He later stated in an interview, "They arranged my transfer without asking me. I haven't signed anything yet, I have to see the contract first. I don't know why this has happened, I know that both Roma and Watford announced my transfer, but they'd have to talk to my representatives first. I never said I wanted to leave Roma. I'll sign after first agreeing to the terms of the contract. I can't understand why this has happened, I came back from my holiday in [[Dubai]] and everyone started telling me my transfer had been officially announced. I'm in Germany right now, how could I sign a contract?"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/jose-holebas-denies-signing-for-watford-24-hours-after-club-announce-his-arrival-10364930.html|title=Jose Holebas denies signing for Watford, 24 hours after club announce his arrival|publisher=www.standard.co.uk|date=3 July 2015}}</ref> Following that claim, and after days of confusion and wondering if Holebas was going to either continue his contact and talks with Watford and eventually sign for them, or if he was going to turn his back on Watford's offer to stay committed to the three-year deal he signed at Roma a year earlier, it was reported that on 5 July that Holebas had decided to revive his contact and discussions with Watford.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-italia.net/68746/holebas-revives-watford-talks|title=Holebas revives Watford talks|publisher=www.football-italia.net|date=5 July 2015}}</ref>
===Watford=== Watford eventually officially completed the signing of Holebas for an initial fee of £1.8 million, which Roma confirmed. Roma also announced on their official website that the move could also include up to £350,000 worth of add-ons.<ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3147564/Watford-agree-signing-Roma-defender-Jose-Holebas-1-8million-deal.html|title=Watford agree signing of Roma defender Jose Holebas in £1.8million deal|publisher=www.dailymail.co.uk|date=2 July 2015}}</ref> On 8 August 2015, he made his debut for the club, playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–2 away league draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in their opening [[2015–16 Premier League]] match and Watford's return to the top division. He picked up a yellow card in the match.
Playing just three games in all competitions in the first two-and-a-half months of the season, he struggled to secure a first place spot in the Watford side, sitting third in the pecking order behind [[Nathan Aké]] and [[Ikechi Anya]] for the starting left-back spot. As a result, rumours circulated that he could be off-loaded already in the January transfer window.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/watford-ready-ditch-greek-international-6553963|title=Watford ready to ditch Greek international defender Jose Holebas – after just THREE GAMES|publisher=www.mirror.co.uk|date=1 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.clubcall.com/watford/holebas-heading-for-january-exit-1783511.html|title=Holebas heading for January exit|publisher=www.clubcall.com|date=29 September 2015}}</ref> Hornets manager [[Quique Sánchez Flores]] insisted that Holebas needed to improve to return to the team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3256089/Watford-defender-Jose-Holebas-needs-improve-win-team-spot-insists-Quique-Sanchez-Flores.html|title=Watford defender Jose Holebas needs to improve to win back his first-team spot, insists Quique Sanchez Flores|publisher=www.dailymail.co.uk|date=1 October 2015}}</ref> After three months of not playing, Holebas returned to the side on 26 December to play the full 90 minutes in a 2–2 league draw away against reigning league champions [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], picking up a yellow card.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/35139930|title=BBC Sport – Chelsea 2–2 Watford|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=26 December 2015}}</ref>
On 7 January 2016, reports surfaced that French [[Ligue 1]] giants [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] were keen on signing Holebas, and that their head coach [[Míchel (footballer)|Míchel]] was seeking to rekindle the relationship that he and Holebas formed whilst working together for a season-and-a-half at Olympiacos.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/watford-transfer-news-jose-holebas-attracting-interest-from-marseille-a3150956.html|title=Watford transfer news: Jose Holebas attracting interest from Marseille|publisher=www.standard.co.uk|date=7 January 2016}}</ref> On 1 March, Holebas complained on social media after being dropped for Aké in a game against Bournemouth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdsport.co.uk/2016/02/jose-holebas-im-sick-of-this-s/ |title=Jose Holebas: "I’m sick of this s***" |publisher=www.wdsport.co.uk |date=1 March 2016}}</ref>
On 24 March 2016, radio station ''Radyospor'' reported that Holebas had been offered to Turkish giants [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]], as a potential replacement for [[Caner Erkin]] if the latter left at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.turkish-football.com/watford-left-back-holebas-offered-to-fenerbahce/ |title=Watford left-back offered to Fenerbahce |publisher=www.turkish-football.com |date=24 March 2016}}</ref> However, Holebas remained at the club, and on 9 April 2016, he thought he scored his first goal with a header just before the break in a 1–1 home draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], helping the club end a poor run of four consecutive league defeats. It was later given as a Seamus Coleman own goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/watford-vs-everton/2043531/report |title=Watford vs Everton 1–1 |publisher=www.goal.com |date=9 April 2016}}</ref>
On 10 September 2016, Holebas scored his first goal for the club in a 4–2 comeback away victory against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37263970|title=West Ham United 2–4 Watford |publisher=www.bbc.com|date=10 September 2016}}</ref> On 16 October, he scored the only goal of an away win against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37599407|title=Middlesbrough 0–1 Watford – BBC Sport|publisher=www.bbc.com|date=16 October 2016}}</ref> In January 2018, Holebas signed a new deal to keep him at Vicarage Road until the summer of 2020.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42612600 |title=Jose Holebas: Watford left-back signs new contract until 2020 |publisher=www.bbc.co.uk |date=8 January 2018 |accessdate=15 January 2018}}</ref> On 26 August 2018, Holebas scored with a lovely touch inside [[Andros Townsend]], looked up, and whipped in a cross that dips and swerved over [[Wayne Hennessey]] and into the top corner, giving his club a two-goal lead in a 2–1 home win game against [[Crystal Palace F.C.]] It was his first goal for the 2018–19 season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/watford-vs-c-palace/390785 |title=Watford 2–1 Crystal Palace: Roberto Pereyra, Jose Holebas seal third straight win |publisher=www.skysports.com |date=26 August 2018 |accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> On 2 September 2018, Holebas helped his club to maintain their perfect start to the Premier League season, continued to display excellent understanding down the left flank by giving two brilliant assists to [[Troy Deeney]] and [[Craig Cathcart]] in a 2–1 home win game against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/sep/02/watford-v-tottenham-hotspur-premier-league-live |title=Watford 2–1 Tottenham |publisher=www.theguardian.com |date=2 September 2018 |accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref> On 10 November 2018, he scored his second goal in the [[2018–19 Premier League|2018–19 season]] in a 1–1 away draw against [[Southampton F.C.]] rescued a point for Watford.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.goal.com/en/news/8/main/2018/11/10/49257692/southampton-1-watford-1-holebas-cranks-up-pressure-on-hugbes |title=Southampton 1 Watford 1: Holebas cranks up pressure on Hugbes |publisher=www.goal.com |date=10 November 2018 |accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref> On 15 December 2018, he curled in a beautiful left-footed strike from the edge of the box, giving a two-goal lead in a 3–2 home win game against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.watfordfc.com/matches/match-review/match-review-watford-3-2-cardiff-city |title=Watford vs Cardiff 3-2|publisher=www.watfordfc.com |date=15 December 2018 |accessdate=15 December 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:20130814 AT-GR Nationalteam Griechenland 2414.JPG|thumb|300px|Holebas (second from bottom left) lining up for Greece against [[Austria national football team|Austria]] in August 2013]]
Holebas being born in [[West Germany]] was eligible to represent [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and through his [[Greeks|Greek]]-[[Uruguayans|Uruguayan]] heritage was also eligible to represent [[Greece national football team|Greece]] or [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in international football. He never appeared for any of the countries at youth level. In an interview about his International ambitions with a Greek reporter, he stated, "My dream growing up was to play for Germany, but my father is Greek so I would be happy to play for Greece." In November 2011, he received Greek citizenship as "Iosif Cholevas," <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sport24.gr/football/omades/Olympiakos/o_holebas_egine_xolevas.1428931.html|publisher=sport24.gr|title=Ο Holebas έγινε Χολέβας!|date=28 October 2011}}</ref> and on the 11th of the same month, he officially made his debut for Greece in a friendly match against [[Russia national football team|Russia]], which ended in a 1–1 draw at the [[Georgios Karaiskakis Stadium]] in [[Piraeus]].
[[File:20130814 AT-GR Jose Holebas 2825.jpg|thumb|left|150 px|Holebas playing for Greece against Austria in 2013]]
In 2012, Holebas was part of Greece's 23-man squad for the [[UEFA Euro 2012]] finals held in [[Poland]] and [[Ukraine]]. He started the first two group games against [[Poland national football team|Poland]] in a 1–1 draw and against [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] in a 2–1 loss and was dropped for the third match due to heavy criticism that his attacking tendency was becoming hazardous to the usually-solid defensive tactics of Greece. Nonetheless, he did come on for the final 30 minutes of the match, playing admirably and assisting Greece in holding on to the 1–0 win against Russia, which took them to the quarter-finals. Here, however, Greece fell to Germany by a score of 4–2, a defeat in which Holebas picked up a suspension for receiving another yellow card after his previous booking in the game against Russia.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/jun/01/world-cup-2014-greece-jose-holebas | title = World Cup 2014: Greece profile – José Holebas| publisher = theguardian.com| date = 20 May 2014}}</ref>
Holebas scored his first international goal for Greece in a 1–0 victory against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] in November 2012, a friendly match played at the [[Aviva Stadium]] in [[Dublin]].
Holebas' impressive 2013–14 season with Olympiacos prompted his nomination from Greek manager [[Fernando Santos (Portuguese footballer)|Fernando Santos]] as a part of the final 23-man squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in [[Brazil]]. He played in all of Greece's matches, which included a 3–0 loss to [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]], a 0–0 draw with [[Japan national football team|Japan]], a 2–1 victory over [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] in the Group Stages, and the 1–1 (5–3 penalty shoot-out) defeat to [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] in the last 16, during which he converted his penalty kick.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/greece/10810255/Greece-World-Cup-2014-squad.html|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|title=Greece World Cup 2014 squad|date=19 May 2014}}</ref>
On 27 March 2015, two days before the crucial [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualification|Euro 2016 qualifier]] for Greece against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], media reports claimed that Holebas had trained normally with his Roma squad after departing from Austria on Tuesday. "On Monday José underwent a radiographic examination of which it was diagnosed that he was suffering from a left rib case injury. The player trained in [[Austria]] under an individual program but was not fit to be available to play against Hungary," the [[Hellenic Football Federation]] (HFF) said in an announcement. The HFF added that reports out of Italy cited by the Greek media "lead to completely erroneous conclusions in regards to the willingness of the player to contribute to his commitments with the national team any further."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/sports/football/greek-football-federation-backs-injured-jose-holebas_1568865.html|publisher=zeenews.india.com|title=Greek football federation backs injured Jose Holebas|date=27 March 2015}}</ref> This was probably the cause for the non-call-up of the player for the national team, creating tension with new Greek manager and former national team teammate [[Georgios Karagounis]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.contra.gr/Soccer/Hellas/National-Greece/holebas-ethniki-greece-hellas-karagounis-roma.3515713.html|publisher=www.contra.gr|title=Χολέμπας στο Contra.gr: "Γελοία αντίδραση το κόψιμό μου"|date=8 June 2015}}</ref> On 4 September 2015, Holebas returned to the national side after being picked by caretaker coach [[Kostas Tsanas]], where he appeared for Greece for the first time in 12 months in Greece's 0–1 home defeat against [[Finland national football team|Finland]] in a Euro 2016 qualifier in Piraeus. The defeat officially ended Greece's hopes of qualification to the [[UEFA Euro 2016|final tournament]] in [[France]] in a poor overall qualifying campaign for Greece.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/qualifiers/season=2016/matches/round=2000446/match=2013983/index.html|title=Greece 0–1 Finland|publisher=www.uefa.com|date=4 September 2015}}</ref>
In [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification]], Holebas played his 38th and last ever cap for Greece when he came on as a second-half substitute in the Greek 2–0 home win over [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]] on 7 October 2016 in Piraeus. Then on 10 October 2016, after a 2–0 away win against [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]], Holebas officially announced his decision to retire from International football because he feels that it is time for the younger footballers of Greece to step up and become Greek international regulars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naftemporiki.gr/story/1158132/apoxorei-apo-tin-ethniki-o-xolempas |title=Αποχωρεί από την Εθνική ο Χολέμπας! |publisher=www.naftemporiki.gr |date=11 October 2016}}</ref> However on 1 September 2017, Holebas admitted he had left the Greek national team due to his dislike of national team coach [[Michael Skibbe]].<ref>http://www.contra.gr/Soccer/Hellas/National-Greece/o-xolempas-adeiase-skimpe-gia-tis-epiloges-paiktwn-sthn-ethnikh.4747512.html</ref>

{{short description|American actor}} {{other people}} {{Infobox person | name = Ben Foster | image = Ben Foster by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Foster at the 2015 [[San Diego Comic-Con]] | birth_name = Benjamin A. Foster | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1980|10|29}} | birth_place = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. | residence = [[New York (state)|New York]] | occupation = Actor | years_active = 1996–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Laura Prepon]]|2018}} | children = 1 | relatives = [[Jon Foster]] (brother) }} '''Benjamin A. Foster''' (born October 29, 1980){{cite web | url = http://www.filmreference.com/film/31/Ben-Foster.html | title = Ben Foster Biography (1980–) | publisher=FilmReference.com | accessdate= October 15, 2013}} is an American actor. He has had roles in films including ''[[The Punisher (2004 film)|The Punisher]]'' (2004), ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'' (2006), ''[[Alpha Dog]]'' (2006), ''[[The Messenger (2009 film)|The Messenger]]'' (2009), ''[[Pandorum]]'' (2009),{{Cite news |last=Ordona |first=Michael |title=Ben Foster puts his heart into ''The Messenger'' |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=November 1, 2009 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/nov/01/entertainment/ca-foster1 |accessdate=November 15, 2010 }} ''[[The Mechanic (2011 film)|The Mechanic]]'' (2011), ''[[Contraband (2012 film)|Contraband]]'' (2012), [[Kill Your Darlings (2013 film)|''Kill Your Darlings'']] (2013), ''[[Lone Survivor (film)|Lone Survivor]]'' (2013), ''[[The Program (2015 film)|The Program]]'' (2015), and ''[[Leave No Trace (film)|Leave No Trace]]'' (2018). He was nominated for a [[Saturn Award]] and a [[Satellite Award]] for his role in ''[[3:10 to Yuma (2007 film)|3:10 to Yuma]]'' (2007){{cite web |title=Ben Foster |work=Yahoo! Movies |year=2010 |url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800332837/bio |accessdate=November 15, 2010 }} and won an [[Independent Spirit Award]] for portraying Tanner Howard in ''[[Hell or High Water (2016 film)|Hell or High Water]]'' (2016).{{cite web|url=https://www.filmindependent.org/blog/2017-film-independent-spirit-awards-winners-announced/|title=2017 Film Independent Spirit Awards Winners Announced! – Film Independent|date=25 February 2017|publisher=}} ==Early life== Foster was born in Boston, Massachusetts, the son of restaurant owners Gillian Kirwan and Steven Foster.{{Cite news |last=Fee |first=Gayle |author2=Laura Raposa |title=Inside Track: Pool barons foster son's fledgling career |work=[[Boston Herald]] |date=September 3, 1995 |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/20531991.html?dids=20531991:20531991&FMT=ABS |accessdate=November 15, 2010}} {{subscription}}{{Cite news |last=Sherman |first=Paul |title=New ''Heights''; After landing the lead role in Barry Levinson's latest film, Boston native Ben Foster is flying |work=[[Boston Herald]] |date=December 9, 1999 |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/47037101.html?dids=47037101:47037101&FMT=ABS |accessdate=November 15, 2010}}{{subscription}}{{Cite news |last=Abel |first=Judy |title=Exploring life’s ‘darker corners’ |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=November 15, 2009 |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2009/11/15/ben_foster_addresses_grief_and_loss_in_the_messenger/?page=2 |accessdate=November 15, 2010 }} He has described his parents as "free-spirited, [[Vietnam]]-protesting hippies".{{cite web |last=Miller |first=Gerri |title=Foster Reaches for the "Heights" |work=JVibe |year=1999 |url=http://www.jvibe.com/popculture/heights.shtml|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000523011623/http://www.jvibe.com/popculture/heights.shtml|archivedate=2000-05-23|accessdate=November 12, 2006 }} He has a younger brother, [[Jon Foster|Jon]], who is also an actor. When Foster was four years old, his family relocated to [[Fairfield, Iowa|Fairfield]], Iowa, after their Boston home was broken into by robbers while they were present. Foster was raised [[Judaism|Jewish]], and had a [[Bar and Bat Mitzvah|Bar Mitzvah]] ceremony.{{Cite news |last=Sragow |first=Michael |title=It's a boy's, boy's, boy's world (and a girl's) |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon.com]] |date=December 16, 1999 |url=http://www.salon.com/entertainment/col/srag/1999/12/16/liberty_heights |accessdate=November 15, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} His paternal grandparents were Celia (Segal) and Abraham Foster, who was a prominent judge and politician in Boston; their families emigrated from Russia.{{cite news |last=Breed |first=Allan G. |title=Ben Foster reaches for new ''Heights'' |work=[[Lawrence Journal-World]] |date=February 4, 1999 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6oEyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=veYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5145,1266634&dq=ben-foster-reaches-for-new-heights |accessdate=December 10, 2007 }}{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/doc/290724968.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec%2027,%201994&author=Indira%20A.R.%20Lakshmanan,%20Globe%20Staff&pub=Boston%20Globe%20(pre-1997%20Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=&desc=A.%20Frank%20Foster,%20judge%20who%20once%20halted%20a%20man's%20beating;%20at%2084 | work=Boston Globe | first=Indira A.R. | last=Lakshmanan | title=A. Frank Foster, judge who once halted a man's beating; at 84 | date=December 27, 1994}}{{cite web|url=http://brezniakrodman.com/obituary/celia-segal-foster/ |title=CELIA ( SEGAL) FOSTER « Brezniak Rodman Funeral Directors |publisher=Brezniakrodman.com |date=2010-06-28 |accessdate=2014-05-12}} While living in Fairfield, he attended the [[Maharishi University of Management]]. ==Career== [[File:Ben Foster (22618765614).jpg|left|thumb|Foster at the [[Toronto Film Festival]] in 2015]] Foster began working as an actor when he was sixteen years old. In 1996 and 1997, he starred in the [[Disney Channel]] television series ''[[Flash Forward]]''. In 2001, he acted in the film ''[[Get Over It (film)|Get Over It]]''. Foster also had a recurring role as [[List of Six Feet Under characters#Russell Corwin|Russell Corwin]] (22 episodes) in the HBO Original Series, ''[[Six Feet Under (TV series)|Six Feet Under]]''. After appearing in the films ''[[11:14]]'' and ''[[The Punisher (2004 film)|The Punisher]]'', Foster appeared in ''[[Hostage (2005 film)|Hostage]]'' with [[Bruce Willis]], [[Kevin Pollak]] and [[Michelle Horn]]. In 2006, Foster appeared in ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'' as the comic-book hero [[Warren Worthington III|Angel / Warren Worthington III]]. In the crime thriller ''[[Alpha Dog]]'', he played the character Jake Mazursky and added [[glaucoma]] drops to his eyes to simulate the appearance of a drug addict in the film.{{cite news |title=X-Men star Foster risks eyesight to play druggie |publisher=Contact Music |date=December 12, 2006 |url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/x-men%20star%20foster%20risks%20eyesight%20to%20play%20druggie_1016263 |accessdate=December 12, 2006 }} In 2007, he played cold-blooded killer and outlaw [[Charlie Prince]] in the [[Western film]] ''[[3:10 to Yuma (2007 film)|3:10 to Yuma]]''.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/the-scotsman/scotland/interview-ben-foster-actor-and-producer-1-2121709 |work=[[The Scotsman]] |title=Interview: Ben Foster, actor and producer |date=February 17, 2012 |accessdate=September 15, 2012 }} In February 2013, he was cast to replace [[Shia LaBeouf]] in the Broadway play ''[[Orphans (Lyle Kessler play)|Orphans]]'' as his first theater performance.{{cite web|last=Lawson|first=Richard|title=Ben Foster to Replace Shia LaBeouf, Esquire Reader, on Broadway|url=https://news.yahoo.com/ben-foster-replaces-shia-labeouf-190602363.html|work=The Atlantic Wire|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=21 February 2013|date=21 February 2013}} In May 2014, it was announced that he would star opposite [[Gillian Anderson]] and [[Vanessa Kirby]] in [[Benedict Andrews]]' new production of ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]'' at the [[Young Vic]] in London.{{cite web|title=Ben Foster and Vanessa Kirby join Young Vic's Streetcar|url=https://www.londontheatre.co.uk/theatre-news/news/ben-foster-and-vanessa-kirby-join-young-vics-streetcar|website=London Theatre|accessdate=9 June 2014}} That production closed on September 19, 2014. The same production transferred to New York in 2016, opening at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn.{{cite web|title=St. Ann's Warehouse – A Young Vic & Joshua Andrews Co-Production|url=http://stannswarehouse.org/show/streetcar-named-desire|website=St. Ann's Warehouse|accessdate=May 9, 2017}} Foster played [[Lance Armstrong]] in the biopic ''[[The Program (2015 film)|The Program]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclingweekly.co.uk/news/latest-news/bikes-lance-armstrong-movie-sold-144586|title=Bikes from Lance Armstrong movie to be sold off|first1=Richard|last1=Windsor|accessdate=2014-11-14|date=2014-11-13 |website=cyclingweekly.co.uk|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]}}{{cite web|title=First Look: Ben Foster as Lance Armstrong in Stephen Frears' Biopic|accessdate=June 20, 2018|date=October 23, 2013 |first1=Scott|last1=Roxborough|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lance-armstrong-biopic-first-photo-650359}} and co-starred in the fantasy adventure ''[[Warcraft (film)|Warcraft]]'', released in June 2016.{{cite web|last=Collura|first=Scott|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/12/05/ben-foster-and-dominic-cooper-head-for-warcraft|title=Ben Foster and Dominic Cooper Head for Warcraft|date=December 4, 2013|publisher=IGN|accessdate=December 5, 2013}} Also in 2016, Foster appeared in ''[[Hell or High Water (2016 film)|Hell or High Water]]'' as the dangerous Tanner Howard, opposite [[Chris Pine]] and [[Jeff Bridges]]. Foster was acclaimed for his roles and has received numerous awards nominations. Foster has continuously received praise from critics for his "intense" and "unhinged" performances in numerous films.{{cite web|author1=[[Bilge Ebiri|Ebiri, Bilge]]|title=Ben Foster on Shooting The Messenger’s Most Harrowing Scenes|url=http://www.vulture.com/2009/11/the_messengers_ben_foster_on.html|website=[[New York (magazine)#Digital expansion and blogs|Vulture]]|publisher=New York Media LLC|accessdate=26 February 2017|date=13 November 2009|quote=Ben Foster has been attracting attention for some time thanks to his intense (sometimes even downright unhinged) portrayals in action flicks...}}{{cite web|author1=[[Lou Lumenick|Lumenick, Lou]]|title=BEST WESTERN|url=https://nypost.com/2007/09/07/best-western/|website=[[New York Post]]|publisher=NYP Holdings, Inc.|accessdate=26 February 2017|date=7 September 2007|quote=The role [of [[Charlie Prince]]] is played with great flamboyance by Ben Foster, who manages to steal scenes left and right from [[Russell Crowe|Crowe]] and [[Christian Bale|Bale]] – no easy feat.}}{{cite web|author1=[[A. O. Scott|Scott, A. O.]]|title=Delivering Bad News and Truths About War|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/13/movies/13messenger.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=26 February 2017|date=12 November 2009|quote=... with this performance Mr. Foster, having shown intriguing promise in “Alpha Dog” and “3:10 to Yuma,” places himself in the first rank of young American screen actors.}} Film critic [[Matt Zoller Seitz]] described Foster in 2016 as "one of those actors who makes even a bad film worth seeing. Sometimes he suggests the film you'd rather be watching."{{cite tweet|author=[[Matt Zoller Seitz]]|user=mattzollerseitz|number=759231040464576512|date=29 July 2016|title=Ben Foster's one of those actors who makes even a bad film worth seeing. Sometimes he suggests the film you'd rather be watching.|accessdate=26 February 2017}} ==Personal life== Foster was in a relationship with German actress [[Antje Traue]], his co-star in the movie ''[[Pandorum]]''. Traue revealed in an interview that she had moved to Los Angeles and lived with Foster until their relationship ended around 2010. {{cite web|url=https://www.focus.de/kultur/medien/kultur-der-schoenste-deutsche-hollywood-import_id_8760630.html|first=Harald|last=Pauli|title=Antje Traue, Der schoenste deutsche Hollywood-Import (in German)|work=Focus Magazin (Nr. 16, 2018)|date=2018-04-14|accessdate=2018-06-08}} Foster began a relationship with actress [[Robin Wright]] in early 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20569270,00.html|title=Robin Wright and Ben Foster Get Cozy|date=February 10, 2012|publisher=People.com|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/robin-wright-46-and-ben-foster-32-affectionate-during-shopping-trip-20122412|title=Robin Wright, 46, and Ben Foster, 32, Affectionate During Shopping Trip|date=December 24, 2012|author=Justin Ravitz|publisher=US Magazine|accessdate=April 19, 2013}} They became engaged in early 2014,{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20774776,00.html|title=Robin Wright and Ben Foster are engaged|date=January 11, 2014|author=Alexis L. Loinaz|publisher=People.com|accessdate=January 11, 2014}} but called off their engagement on November 12, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/robin-wright-ben-foster-split-call-off-engagement-details-20141211|title=Robin Wright and Ben Foster Split, Call Off 10-Month Engagement – Find Out What Went Wrong|date=November 12, 2014|first=Sierra|last=Marquina|work=Us Magazine|accessdate=November 13, 2014}} Foster and Wright reconciled in early 2015,{{cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/03/robin-wright-april-2015-cover|title=Introducing Robin Wright, Our April 2015 Cover Star|publisher=Vanity Fair}} however, on August 29, 2015, they announced they were ending their second engagement.{{cite web|last1=Webber|first1=Stephanie|title=Robin Wright, Ben Foster Call Off Engagement For the Second Time|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/robin-wright-ben-foster-call-off-engagement-for-the-second-time--2015298|accessdate=29 August 2015}} In October 2016, Foster announced his engagement to actress [[Laura Prepon]].{{cite web|url=http://people.com/style/laura-prepon-ben-foster-engagement-ring/|title=Laura Prepon and Ben Foster Are Engaged! See Her Gorgeous New Ring|date=5 October 2016|publisher=}} In January 2017, it was announced that the couple were expecting their first child.{{cite web|url=http://people.com/babies/laura-prepon-pregnant-baby-bump-sundance-film-festival/|title=Pregnant Laura Prepon Steps Out with Baby Bump at Sundance Film Festival|date=24 January 2017|publisher=}} Prepon gave birth to their daughter Ella in August 2017. Foster and Prepon married in June 2018.{{cite web|url=https://people.com/movies/laura-prepon-ben-foster-are-married/|title=Laura Prepon and Ben Foster Are Married! 'Thank You for All the Love'|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=June 3, 2018|accessdate=June 4, 2018}} Foster practices [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]].{{cite web|url=https://www.connectsavannah.com/savannah/extreme-closeup-ben-foster/Content?oid=2131727|title=Extreme closeup: Ben Foster|last=DeYoung|first=Bill|work=[[Connect Savannah]]|date=October 27, 2009|accessdate=November 15, 2010}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! |nationalcaps4 = 7 |nationalgoals4 = 1 |club-update = 13:02, 4 March 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 18:52, 25 July 2017 (UTC) }} '''Étienne Capoue''' (born 11 July 1988) is a French professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]. He can play as either a [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfielder]] or [[Defender (association football)|defender]]. Capoue was a [[France national youth football team|French youth international]] having earned caps at [[France national under-18 football team|under-18]], [[France national under-19 football team|under-19]], and [[France national under-21 football team|under-21]] level. Capoue served as [[Captain (association football)|captain]] for a portion of his stint with the latter team. He is the younger brother of [[US Boulogne|Boulogne]] player [[Aurélien Capoue]].
== Club career ==
=== Early career === Capoue was born in the [[Communes of France|commune]] of [[Niort]] in Deux-Sèvres and began his career playing for hometown club [[Chamois Niortais F.C.|Chamois Niortais]]. In 2002, he departed the club and joined FC Chauray, a local club in [[Poitou-Charentes]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://jcs9.free.fr/affiche_articles.php?article=153 | title = Le TFC, c'est la famille! | date = | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = Jeunes Citoyens Supporters | language = French}}</ref> Capoue stayed at the club for two years before joining [[Angers SCO]] in [[Pays de la Loire]]. While playing in a youth league match against [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]], Capoue drew the attention of the club's scouts who offered the player a one-week trial. Prior to agreeing to the internship, he was also approached by [[Lille OSC|Lille]], [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]], and [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]]. Capoue chose Toulouse because of the club's training facilities and the good weather.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2006/12/06/28131-TFC-Etienne-Capoue-prend-son-envol.html | title = Etienne Capoue prend son envol | date = 6 December 2006 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = La Depeche | language = French}}</ref>
=== Toulouse === [[File:Étienne Capoue 2008-07-09.JPG|thumb|left|180px|Capoue with Toulouse in 2008]] Capoue began his club career with Toulouse in 2006 playing on the club's under-18 team. During the early portion of the [[Championnat de France amateur 2007–08|2007–08 season]], he played on the club's [[Championnat de France amateur]] team in the fourth division making eight appearances. Midway through [[2007–08 Ligue 1|the season]], Capoue was called up to the senior team by manager [[Alain Casanova]]. On 8 December 2007, he made his professional debut appearing as a substitute in a 1–0 victory over Lille.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007/2008&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J17&num_ordre=10 | title = Toulouse v. Lille Match Report | date = 8 December 2007 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | language = French}}</ref> The following week, Capoue made his first professional start against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] at the [[Parc des Princes]]. Toulouse won the match 2–1 with Capoue playing 71 minutes.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007/2008&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J18&num_ordre=7 | title = Paris SG v. Toulouse Match Report | date = 15 December 2007 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | language = French}}</ref>
On 7 February 2008, Capoue, along with teammate [[Cheikh M'Bengue]], signed his first professional contract agreeing to a three-year deal until 2011.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/20080207_173707Dev.html | title = Capoue passe pro | date = 7 February 2008 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[L'Equipe]] | language = French}}</ref> For the [[2008–09 Ligue 1|2008–09 season]], Casanova paired the young defensive midfielder with former youth teammate [[Moussa Sissoko]] and new signing [[Étienne Didot]], who arrived from [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]]. The trio performed well in the midfield with Capoue flourishing making 36 total appearances. On 18 October 2008, Capoue scored his first professional goal against Bordeaux in a 2–1 defeat.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2008/2009&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J09&num_ordre=2 | title = Bordeaux v. Toulouse Match Report | date = 18 October 2008 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | language = French}}</ref> During the season, he also received 14 [[Penalty card|yellow card]]s in all competitions, second to only [[Siaka Tiéné]] of [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]] in the league. For his efforts, he was nominated for the [[Ligue 1 2008-09#Young Player of the Year|Ligue 1 Young Player of the Year]] award and awarded a contract extension until 2013 by his club.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.toulouse7.com/2009/11/26/sissoko-prolonge-au-tfc/ | title = Sissoko prolonge un an | date = 26 November 2009 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = Toulouse 7 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.rmc.fr/edito/sport/76169/capoue-en-espagne-ca-joue/ | title = En Espagne, ça joue | date = 17 April 2009 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = Radio Monte Carlo | language = French}}</ref>
During the [[2009–10 Ligue 1|2009–10 season]], Capoue appeared regularly in the first team and drew interest from Italian club [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] and [[Premier League]] clubs [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11800_5617263,00.html | title = Capoue focused on Toulouse | date = 8 October 2009 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = Sky Sports }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_4962962,00.html | title = Capoue flattered by interest | date = 23 February 2009 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = Sky Sports }}</ref> On 26 November 2009, Toulouse responded to the interest by reaching an agreement with Capoue on a one-year contract extension until 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2009/11/27/724787-TFC-prolongation-de-contrat-pour-Sissoko-M-Bengue-Capoue-et-Nounkeu.html | title = prolongation de contrat pour Sissoko, M'Bengue, Capoue et Nounkeu | date = 27 November 2009 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = Le Depeche | language = French }}</ref> Capoue appeared in 41 total matches for the season collecting 17 total yellow cards, 13 of which came in Ligue 1, leading all players.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/stat/cartons_joueur.asp?code_type_evt=AVE&saison=2009/2010 | title = Cartons par jouer | date = | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | language = French}}</ref>
In July 2013, Toulouse accepted a reported £9.5 million bid from [[Premier League]] side [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City have Etienne Capoue bid accepted by Toulouse |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23479981 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 July 2013 |accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref> However, personal terms were not agreed and the deal was not finalised. On 15 August 2013, he completed an €11m (£9.3m) transfer to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/aug/09/etienne-capoue-tottenham-snubs-cardiff|title=Tottenham secure Etienne Capoue from Toulouse in €11m deal|date=9 August 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013|author=David Hytner|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23620554|title=Etienne Capoue: Tottenham agree £9m deal for France midfielder|date=9 August 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013|author=David Ornstein|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
=== Tottenham Hotspur === [[File:Étienne Capoue vs Arsenal - 1 September 2013.jpg|thumb|150px|Capoue playing for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 2013.]] On 15 August 2013, Tottenham Hotspur officially announced the signing of Capoue. The day before the announcement of Capoue, Tottenham and France's first choice goalkeeper, [[Hugo Lloris]] told French paper L'Equipe that joining Tottenham is a big step in Capoue's career. He stated his delight to see the fellow countrymen join Tottenham.<ref>http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/422013/Spurs-shot-stopper-Hugo-Lloris-looking-forward-to-linking-up-with-Etienne-Capoue</ref> Capoue made his debut for Spurs on 18 August 2013, replacing [[Mousa Dembélé (footballer, born 1987)|Mousa Dembélé]] in a 1–0 win away to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23653983 "Crystal Palace 0–1 Tottenham"] BBC Sport. 18 August 2013. Retrieved 20 August 2013.</ref>
=== Watford === On 6 July 2015, Capoue joined newly promoted [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] for a reported club-record transfer fee of £6.3 million (€9 million).<ref>{{cite web|title=Etienne Capoue: Watford sign Tottenham midfielder|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33410824|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=4 September 2015|date=6 July 2015}}</ref><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jul/06/watford-sign-etienne-capoue-tottenham-club-record-fee</ref>
He began his second season at Watford with four goals in his first six games, including the opening goal against Manchester United in a 3–1 win at Vicarage Road and another in a 4–2 comeback win against West Ham United.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smyth|first1=Rob|title=Watford 3–1 Manchester United|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/sep/18/watford-manchester-united-premier-league-live|website=The Guardian|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=18 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Morgan|first1=Richard|title=West Ham United 2–4 Watford: Hornets record first Premier League win of the season|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/west-ham-vs-watford/356374|website=Sky Sports|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=18 September 2016}}</ref>
== International career == Capoue was eligible to play for [[Guadeloupe]], due to his father being from there.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3308130/Watford-s-Etienne-Capoue-Maybe-attitude-comes-dad-Caribbean-lazy-people.html|title=Capoue believes his 'very lazy' attitude is down to Caribbean roots|website=Mail Online|accessdate=2016-03-07}}</ref> Capoue has been active with [[France national football team|France]] on the [[France national youth football team|youth level]]. He has received caps with the [[France national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[France national under-19 football team|under-19]] teams. Capoue made his youth international debut with the under-18 team on 14 March 2006 in a 2–1 victory over [[Germany national youth football team|Germany]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m18ans/290655.shtml | title = La France remporte la première manche (2–1) | date = 14 March 2006 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> He finished the under-18 campaign with four appearances. He made his debut with the under-19 team at the 2006 edition of the Sendaï Cup in Japan in the opening match against the [[Tōhoku region]] national team.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m19ans/319328.shtml | title = Victoire pour débuter (4–1) | date = 31 August 2006 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> In the team's next group stage match against [[Japan national football team|Japan]], Capoue scored his first youth international goal in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.fff.fr///selections/m19ans/319919.shtml | title = Deuxième succès (3–1) | date = 2 September 2006 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> On 23 January 2007, he scored his second under-17 goal in a 2–0 win against [[Turkey national youth football team|Turkey]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m19ans/actualite/354085.shtml | title = Joli succès tricolore (2–0) | date = 23 January 2007 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> During [[2007 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship elite qualification|qualification]] for the [[2007 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship]], Capoue scored his only goal in a 3–1 positive result against [[Poland national under-19 football team|Poland]] in the Elite Round.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m19ans/actualite/375103.shtml | title = Débuts victorieux (3–1) | date = 8 May 2007 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> At the UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship, Capoue missed the first two group stage matches, but appeared in the team final one against [[Russia national football team|Russia]] and the team's semi-final defeat on penalties to [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m19ans/actualite/387146.shtml | title = France et Russie dos à dos (0–0) | date = 21 July 2007 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m19ans/actualite/387265.shtml | title = L'Espagne rejoint la Grèce (0–0, 4 tab 2) | date = 24 July 2007 | accessdate = 18 July 2010 | publisher = [[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref>
On 15 August 2012, Capoue made his debut for the [[France national football team|French senior team]] in a friendly match against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]].<ref>[https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1681011.html]</ref> On 11 September 2012, he scored his first goal for France in a 3–1 [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|World Cup qualifier]] win over [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]] at the [[Stade de France]].<ref>[http://www.goal.com/en/match/88546/france-vs-belarus/report]</ref>
