{{EngvarB|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jerome Sinclair | image = | caption = | fullname = Jerome Terence Sinclair{{Hugman|26984|accessdate=2 February 2017}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1996|9|20}} | birth_place = [[Birmingham]], England | height = {{height|m=1.81}}{{cite web |url=https://www.watfordfc.com/teams/first-team/jerome-sinclair-0 |title=Jerome Sinclair |publisher=Watford F.C. |accessdate=26 June 2017}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] (on loan from [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]) | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = 2006–2011 | youthclubs1 = [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] | youthyears2 = 2011–2012 | youthclubs2 = [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|Liverpool]] | years1 = 2012–2016 | clubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps1 = 2 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2015 | clubs2 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) | caps2 = 1 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2016– | clubs3 = [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] | caps3 = 9 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2017 | clubs4 = → [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] (loan) | caps4 = 5 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2018 | clubs5 = → [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] (loan) | caps5 = 13 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2019– | clubs6 = → [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] (loan) | caps6 = 6 | goals6 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2011–2012 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 5 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | nationalyears2 = 2012 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 5 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | club-update = 18:40, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Jerome Terence Sinclair''' (born 20 September 1996) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[forward (association football)|forward]] for [[EFL League One|League One]] team [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] on loan from [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]. He represented England up to [[England national under-17 football team|under-17 level]]. He spent his youth at [[West Bromwich Albion]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], making his senior debut for the latter at the age of 16 years and 6 days in 2012, their youngest player of all time. He went on to make four further appearances for Liverpool after a brief loan spell at [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] where he appeared just once. He signed for Watford in July 2016 for a fee of £4 million. He spent the second half of the 2016–17 season on loan to [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] and the first half of the following season on loan at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] before his loan to Oxford for the second half of the season. ==Early life== Sinclair was born in [[Dudley Road Hospital]], [[Birmingham]], and raised in the [[Quinton, Birmingham|Quinton]] district.{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/birmingham-citys-jerome-sinclair-couldnt-12535802 |title=Birmingham City's Jerome Sinclair: This is why I couldn't turn Gianfranco Zola down |first=Aidan |last=McCartney |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=3 February 2017}} He began playing organised football as a seven-year-old with Phoenix United, part of a scheme designed to use sport to keep youngsters off the streets and promote positive values. He was spotted while playing for Phoenix United, invited to a trial with [[West Bromwich Albion]], and joined that club as a schoolboy at the age of eight.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blackcountry/content/articles/2006/11/15/bc_cin_phoenix_united_feature.shtml |title=Phoenix United – giving talented kids a goal |publisher=BBC Black Country |date=9 September 2008 |accessdate=3 February 2017}} As a boy, he supported [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and idolised [[Thierry Henry]].{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/127203-meet-our-nexlions-stars-part-two |title=Meet our NexLions stars: Part two |first=Steve |last=Hunter |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=13 December 2012 |accessdate=3 February 2017}} When Sinclair joined [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]'s youth academy, his father moved to Liverpool with him, while his mother, sister and four brothers remained at home in Birmingham.{{cite news |url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/sports/football-jerome-sinclair-could-be-reds-next-star?nopaging=1 |title=Football: Jerome Sinclair could be the Reds' next star |first=Gary |last=Lim |newspaper=The New Paper |location=Singapore |date=2 October 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2017}} While with West Brom, he had attended [[Sandwell Academy]];{{cite magazine |url=http://www.sandwellacademy.com/Uploads/documents/magazine/issue01.pdf |format=PDF |title=Sports round-up |first=Ashley |last=Bailey |magazine=The Student Voice |publisher=Sandwell Academy |page=23 |date=Spring 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.esfa.co.uk/competitions/?2010/Boys/u14b_sc/6 |title=2010–2011 competitions: ESFA Under 14 Premier League Schools' Cup: Round 6 |publisher=English Schools' Football Association |accessdate=5 February 2017}} as customary with Liverpool's academy recruits, he continued his education at [[Rainhill High School]] in [[St Helens, Merseyside|St Helens]].{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/homework-important-footwork-brendan-rodgers-6275372 |title=Videos: Homework is as important as footwork, Brendan Rodgers tells the next generation of Liverpool FC stars |first=Phil |last=Kirkbride |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=6 November 2013 |accessdate=3 February 2017}} He got good grades in his [[GCSE]]s, and went on to study for an [[A level]] in business studies.{{cite news |url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/sport/football/Premiership/article1500239.ece |title=Soup kitchens to superstars |first=Jonathan |last=Northcroft |newspaper=Sunday Times |location=London |date=28 December 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2017}} ==Club career== ===Liverpool=== ====Academy==== Liverpool signed Sinclair as a 14-year-old from the [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] youth academy in the summer of 2011.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/9567196/Liverpool-teenager-Jerome-Sinclair-set-to-become-clubs-youngest-ever-player-aged-16-years-and-six-days.html |title=Liverpool teenager Jerome Sinclair set to become club's youngest ever player aged 16 years and six days |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} The Liverpool staff compared him to [[Raheem Sterling]].{{cite news |url=http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/A258058424/GPS?sid=wikipedia |title=Ciss is one for Kenny |newspaper=The People |location=London |date=5 June 2011 |page=54 |accessdate=2 February 2017 |via=Infotrac Newsstand |subscription=y}} He spent most of the 2011–12 season with the Under-16s before coach [[Mike Marsh (footballer)|Mike Marsh]] gave him a run of four games with the Under-18s at the end of the season. He impressed greatly in those games, though he failed to find the back of the net. On 14 July 2012, Sinclair came off the bench to score a hat trick against [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] in an Under-18s pre-season friendly. In all, Sinclair netted eight goals in the six Under-18s pre-season friendly games in the run up to the 2012–13 Academy Under 18s season. He went on to score his first competitive goals for the Under-18s on 25 August 2012, hitting a brace in a 3–3 draw with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} ====Reserves and first-team debut==== While still only 15, Sinclair was called up to Rodolfo Borrell's [[NextGen Series (2011–13)|NextGen Series]] side for the away match with defending champions [[Inter Milan]] in September 2012, after first-team manager [[Brendan Rodgers]] included a number of young players in his [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] squad. He started the match and performed well, winning a [[penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] that [[Krisztián Adorján]] converted and going close himself on more than one occasion.{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/liverpool-inter-milan-nextgen-jerome-sinclair-krisztian-386290 |title=Liverpool youngsters edged out by NextGen champions Inter Milan |first=Adrian |last=Back |newspaper=International Business Times |date=20 September 2012 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} Rodgers called Sinclair up to the first team for the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] third-round tie away to his boyhood club, West Bromwich Albion, on 26 September. At the age of 16 years and 6 days, he came off the bench in the 81st minute to replace [[Samed Yeşil]] in the 2–1 win at [[The Hawthorns]], thus breaking [[Jack Robinson (footballer born 1993)|Jack Robinson]]'s record as Liverpool's youngest ever player.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19645199 |title=West Brom 1–2 Liverpool |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} For the remainder of the [[2012–13 Liverpool F.C. season|2012–13 season]] Sinclair continued to play for Liverpool U18s, but his 2013–14 season was disrupted by injury.{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-fc-u21s-2-0-chelsea-8756434 |title=Liverpool FC U21s 2–0 Chelsea U21s: Jerome Sinclair could be next Academy graduate heading to first team and Sergi Canos' form going from strength to strength – five things we learned |first=Andy |last=Kelly |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=3 March 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} Up to the beginning of March 2015, Sinclair scored 22 goals for Liverpool youth teams at various levels,{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} including 6 goals in 7 [[2014–15 UEFA Youth League|UEFA Youth League]] games{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/season=2015/clubs/club=2606417/index.html |title=UEFA Youth League: Liverpool FC |publisher=UEFA |date=10 April 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} as well as an impressive finish against [[Manchester United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Manchester United U21]], beating [[Víctor Valdés]] at his near post,{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11661/9682179/manchester-united-u21s-beat-liverpool-2-1-as-victor-valdes-makes-first-appearance-for-the-club |title=Manchester United U21s beat Liverpool 2-1 as Victor Valdes makes first appearance for the club |publisher=Sky Sports |date=27 January 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} and a solo effort against Chelsea U21. He was one of several youngsters to travel to a [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] tie against [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] in February, but was not included in the matchday squad as Liverpool were eliminated [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|on penalties]].{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11669/9731634/europa-league-jordan-henderson-and-philippe-coutinho-absent-for-liverpool-tie-at-besiktas |title=Jordan Henderson and Philippe Coutinho absent for Liverpool at Besiktas |publisher=Sky Sports |date=25 February 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2017}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31627521 |title=Besiktas 1–0 Liverpool |first=Mike |last=Whalley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 February 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} On 16 March 2015, Sinclair was loaned to [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], where he linked up with academy teammate [[Sheyi Ojo]].{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/181788-sinclair-joins-wigan-on-youth-loan-deal |title=Sinclair joins Wigan on youth loan deal |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=16 March 2015 |accessdate=17 March 2015}} The next day, he made his [[Football League]] debut in what proved to be his only Wigan appearance, replacing [[Marc-Antoine Fortuné]] for the final eight minutes of a 2–0 loss to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] at the [[DW Stadium]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31809691 |title=Wigan 0–2 Watford |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=3 December 2015 |date=17 March 2015}} On returning to Liverpool, Sinclair made his [[Premier League]] debut as a 68th-minute substitute for [[Rickie Lambert]] in a 1–1 draw away to champions [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 10 May.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32571658 |title=Chelsea 1–1 Liverpool |first=Marc |last=Higginson |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 May 2015 |accessdate=13 July 2015}} On his first appearance of the 2015–16 season, away to [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] in the [[FA Cup]] on 8 January 2016, Sinclair scored his first senior goal for Liverpool in a 2–2 draw.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35155398 |title=Exeter City 2–2 Liverpool |first=Gary |last=Rose |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 January 2016 |accessdate=8 January 2016}} Ten days later he confirmed that he would leave Liverpool at the end of the season, suggesting he wanted to play in Spain.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35342040 |title=Jerome Sinclair: Liverpool youngster to leave the club |first=Simon |last=Stone |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 January 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} In April, an offer from [[AFC Bournemouth]] of £4 million plus add-ons was accepted by the club but rejected by the player.{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-hope-jerome-sinclair-tribunal-11372756 |title=Liverpool hope for Sinclair tribunal windfall |first=Neil |last=Jones |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=23 May 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} ===Watford=== In the January 2016 transfer window, Liverpool had rejected an offer of £1.5 million for Sinclair from Premier League club Watford. On 21 May, Sinclair agreed to join that club when his current contract expired.{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-striker-jerome-sinclair-join-11366148 |title=Liverpool striker Jerome Sinclair to join Watford on four-year contract |first=Neil |last=Jones |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=21 May 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} Because Sinclair was aged under 24, Liverpool were due a developmental fee; the clubs settled on £4 million, and Sinclair signed a five-year contract.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36670308 |title=Jerome Sinclair: Watford sign out-of-contract Liverpool striker |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 June 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}} He did not make his debut until 3 December, as a 94th-minute substitute in a defeat by West Bromwich Albion,{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38113785 |title=West Bromwich Albion 3–1 Watford |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 December 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} and made his first start a few days later against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], a match in which City won at home for the first time since mid-September and [[BBC Sport]]'s reporter described Sinclair as "a peripheral figure".{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38232213 |title=Manchester City 2–0 Watford |first=Jonathan |last=Jurejko |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} An approach in late December by Championship club [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] to take him on loan was rebuffed because manager [[Walter Mazzarri]] felt he was needed as cover,{{cite news |url=http://talksport.com/football/former-liverpool-striker-jerome-sinclair-told-fight-his-place-watford-161228221861 |title=Former Liverpool striker Jerome Sinclair told to fight for his place at Watford |publisher=TalkSport |date=28 December 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} and Sinclair scored his first goal for Watford in their FA Cup third-round tie against [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] on 7 January 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38474747 |title=Watford 2–0 Burton Albion |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 January 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} Towards the end of the transfer window, Mazzarri stated that Sinclair needed to gain experience and was free to go out on loan if he so wished.{{cite news |url=http://www.hertfordshiremercury.co.uk/watford-boss-admits-nottingham-forest-birmingham-city-target-jerome-sinclair-can-leave-on-loan/story-30096863-detail/story.html |title=Watford boss admits Nottingham Forest & Birmingham City target Jerome Sinclair can leave on loan |first=Matt |last=Storey |newspaper=Hertfordshire Mercury |date=30 January 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} ====Birmingham City (loan)==== On 31 January 2017, Sinclair moved to Championship club [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38798273 |title=Birmingham sign Arsenal's Krystian Bielik and Watford's Jerome Sinclair on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} He went straight into the starting eleven for the next match, at home to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], partnering [[Lukas Jutkiewicz]], and was replaced after 67 minutes with the score still goalless; Birmingham won the match 1–0.{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/birmingham-city-1-fulham-0-12556615 |title=Birmingham City 1 Fulham 0 – report, stats and video as Gianfranco Zola picks up first win in charge |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=4 February 2017 |accessdate=5 February 2017}} He appeared regularly during February, but the last of his five appearances came as a very late substitute in a home defeat against [[Leeds United]] on 3 March. ====Sunderland (loan)==== Having played just 27 minutes of Premier League football for his parent club in the 2017–18 season,{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/jerome-sinclair/269271/ |title=J. Sinclair |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=30 July 2018}} Sinclair joined [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], newly relegated to [[EFL League One|League One]], on loan for the 2018–19 season,{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44961340 |title=Jerome Sinclair: Watford forward loaned to Sunderland for the 2018-19 season |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 July 2018 |accessdate=30 July 2018}} but the loan was cut short by mutual agreement in January 2019.{{cite news|url=https://www.sunderlandecho.com/sport/football/sunderland-afc/jerome-sinclair-looks-set-for-swift-sunderland-reunion-as-he-heads-for-league-one-rivals-1-9568268 |title=Jerome Sinclair looks set for swift Sunderland reunion as he heads for League One rivals |newspaper=Sunderland Echo |date=31 January 2019 |first=Phil |last=Smitrh |accessdate=31 January 2019}} ====Oxford United (loan)==== On transfer deadline day in January 2019, [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] announced that they had signed Sinclair on loan until the end of the [[2018–19 Oxford United F.C. season|2018–19 season]].{{cite news |url=https://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/oxfordunited/usnews/17400413.deadline-day-watford-striker-jerome-sinclair-joins-oxford-united-on-loan/ |first=David |last=Pritchard |title=DEADLINE DAY: Watford striker Jerome Sinclair joins Oxford United on loan |newspaper=Oxford Mail |date=31 January 2019 |accessdate=31 January 2019}} His first Oxford goals came in a home victory over [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] on 2 March 2019, in which he scored twice.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47340174 |title=Oxford United 2 Scunthorpe 1 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 March 2019 |accessdate=2 March 2019}} ==International career== Sinclair has represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]] and [[England national under-17 football team|under-17 level]]. He made his under-16 debut on 27 October 2011,{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/S/jerome-sinclair |title=Profile: Jerome Sinclair |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=2 February 2017}} and scored as England beat [[Wales national under-16 football team|Wales]] 4–0 in the 2011 [[Victory Shield]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/archive/gilliead-stars-in-england-win |title=Gilliead stars in England win |first=Dan |last=King |publisher=Newcastle United F.C. |date=27 October 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} He also scored twice in the 2012 [[Montaigu Tournament]], earning England wins against host nation [[France national under-16 football team|France]], and [[Morocco national under-16 football team|Morocco]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7PM02rEQCw0C&pg=PA409&lpg=PA409 |title=Playfair Football Annual 2012–2013 |editor-first1=Glenda |editor-last1=Rollin |editor-first2=Jack |editor-last2=Rollin |lastauthoramp=y |publisher=Headline |location=London |year=2012 |page=409 |isbn=978-0-7553-6357-5}} He scored his first goal for the under-17 team on 31 August 2012, opening the scoring in a 4–1 win against [[Turkey national under-17 football team|Turkey]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tff.org/Default.aspx?pageID=529&macID=113922 |title=St George's Park Tournament (U-17 National Team) England 4 Turkey 1 |publisher=Turkish Football Association |accessdate=2 February 2017}} He played twice in the [[2013 UEFA European Under-17 Championship qualifying round|2013 European U17 Championship qualifying round]] matches in [[Estonia]],{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2013/teams/player=250056570/index.html |title=UEFA European Under-17 Championship: 2013: Jerome Sinclair |publisher=UEFA |date=27 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028224459/http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2013/teams/player=250056570/index.html |archivedate=28 October 2012 |df= }} and was selected for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-17 Championship elite round|elite round of qualifying]] but had to withdraw from the squad because of injury.{{cite web |url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/archive/gilliead-called-up |title=Gilliead called up |first=Dan |last=King |publisher=Newcastle United F.C. |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=2 February 2017}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 8 January 2019}} {| '''Stefano Chuka Okaka''' ({{IPA-it|ˈsteːfano oˈkaːka}}; born 9 August 1989) is an Italian [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Udinese Calcio|Udinese]] on loan from English club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].
==Club career== ===Roma=== Born in [[Castiglione del Lago]], Umbria, Italy to [[Nigeria]]n parents who later obtained Italian citizenship, Okaka joined the [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] youth system in 2004. He was part of the team that won the [[Trofeo Giacinto Facchetti|U-20 national title]] in 2005 and scored goals against Juventus in the semi-final and Atalanta in the final.
On 29 September 2005, he made his debut with the first team in the [[UEFA Cup]], playing against [[Aris Thessaloniki F.C.|Aris]]. He thus became the youngest footballer to debut in an international competition for an Italian team.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://it.uefa.com/competitions/uefacup/history/season=2005/round=2208/match=81841/index.html|publisher=UEFA.com|language=Italian|title=Roma in scioltezza|accessdate=15 January 2008|date=29 September 2005}}</ref> Okaka scored his first official goal for Roma in a [[Coppa Italia]] match against [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] on 8 December 2005, with a powerful run from midfield and a precise shot to the left of the goalkeeper, making him the youngest goalscorer in the competition.<ref name="Stefano Okaka could be top Italy striker, says Sampdoria coach"/> He made his [[Serie A]] debut with the club later that month, on 18 December 2005, at the age of 16 years and 125 days, in a 1–1 away draw against [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]].<ref name="Stefano Okaka could be top Italy striker, says Sampdoria coach"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/sport/cards/i-piu-giovani-esordire-serie-a/stefano-okaka.shtml|title=I più giovani a esordire in Serie A Pellegri come Amadei quando la carriera inizia a 15 anni|publisher=Il Corriere della Sera|language=Italian|author1=Fiorenzo Radogna|date=21 November 2016|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/speciali/statistiche/2006/giocatori/presenze_okaka_chuka_ste.shtml|title=Stefano OKAKA CHUKA|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref> He made several more appearances for the senior squad, scoring his first [[Serie A]] goal nine months later, on 17 September 2006, the last of three Roma goals in a 3–1 win over [[A.C. Siena|Siena]], just 38 days after his 17th birthday, after coming on as a substitute for [[Francesco Totti]]. He also made his debut in the [[UEFA Champions League]] later that month, in a 2–1 away loss to [[Valencia CF|Valencia]], on 27 September.<ref name="Stefano Okaka could be top Italy striker, says Sampdoria coach">{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/sampdoria/story/2036404/stefano-okaka-could-be-top-italy-striker-says-sampdoria-coach-sinisa-mihajlovic|title=Stefano Okaka could be top Italy striker, says Sampdoria coach|publisher=ESPN FC|author1=Ben Gladwell|date=15 September 2014|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref>
He was subsequently loaned to [[Serie B]] side [[Modena F.C.|Modena]] for the [[2007–08 Serie B|2007–08 season]] in order to gain some first team experience. Okaka had a fairly good season at Modena, scoring seven times in 33 appearances.
After returning to Roma, he signed a new contract which lasted until 30 June 2012. As a part of it, he earned a gross annual salary of €0.6M in the first two seasons, which then increased to €0.7M and €0.9M.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asroma.it/NewsDoc.aspx?Categoria=ITComunicatiFinanziari&Documento=9547|title=Prolungato il contratto economico per le prestazioni sportive di Stefano Okapa|date=16 October 2008|accessdate=18 June 2010|work=AS Roma|language=Italian}}</ref> He also spent a six-month loan period at [[Brescia Calcio|Brescia]] in Serie B from January to June 2009, where he scored two goals in 16 appearances.
On August 2009, he scored his first goal with Roma in a continental competition, the final goal in a 7–1 result defeat of [[K.A.A. Gent|Gent]] in the second leg of the [[2009–10 UEFA Europa League]] third qualifying round. He scored again in the Europa League in Roma's 2–0 win over [[PFC CSKA Sofia|CSKA Sofia]] and in Roma's 2–1 win over Fulham. His last goal with Roma was an 88th-minute winner against Siena.
On 1 February 2010, he joined Fulham on loan until the end of the season. He made his debut for Fulham in the 1–0 win over [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on 3 February 2010. He scored his first goal for the club on 14 February 2010 in a 5th round [[FA Cup]] tie at home to [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/8506655.stm |title=Fulham 4 – 0 Notts County |work=[[BBC]] |date=14 February 2010 |accessdate=14 February 2010}}</ref> He scored his first league goal for the club against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on 4 April 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8599455.stm |title=Fulham 2 – 1 Wigan |work=[[BBC]] |date=4 April 2010 |accessdate=4 April 2010}}</ref> He was cup-tied for Fulham's run to the [[2010 UEFA Europa League Final]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/juventus-vs-fulham/preview/206882 |title=Juventus vs Fulham |publisher=Sky Sports |date=11 March 2010 |accessdate=29 August 2016}}</ref>
In January 2011 he moved to [[F.C. Bari 1908|Bari]] on loan. There, he scored his first goal against [[US Lecce|Lecce]] for 1–0 win. In this game he and [[Kamil Glik]] marking their debuts for Bari. He scored one further goal for Bari that season. Okaka sustained an injury in round 30 and missed the rest of the season.
In August 2011, Okaka was attacked by Roma fans after a training session for allegedly not wishing to sign autographs.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Landolina|first1=Salvatore|title=Roma Condemn Fan Attacks On Ahmed Barusso & Stefano Okaka|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/2176/serie-a/2011/08/10/2614011/roma-condemn-fan-attacks-on-ahmed-barusso-stefano-okaka|accessdate=21 December 2015|publisher=Goal|date=10 August 2011}}</ref>
After failing to make a single appearance for Roma in the first half of the season, on 22 January 2012, he joined [[Parma F.C.|Parma]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Coerts|first1=Stefan|title=Official: Parma sign Roma's Stefano Okaka on loan|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/10/italy/2012/01/22/2860468/official-parma-sign-romas-stefano-okaka-on-loan|publisher=Goal|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> He scored his first Parma goal on 7 March 2012, the opener in a 2–2 against Fiorentina. He netted his second goal on 21 April from the spot against Cesena. He scored his third against Palermo four days later.
===Parma=== Having returned to Roma at the end of the season Okaka signed a permanent deal with Parma on 20 August. The following day he was loaned to the newly promoted [[Serie B]] club [[Spezia Calcio|Spezia]] where he made 38 appearances, scoring seven goals and assisting six more. After his loan spell, he returned to Parma for the 2013–14 season, making only two Serie A matches as a substitute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fcparma.com/flashnews/shirt-numbers-2013-14?lang=en|title=Shirt numbers 2013–14|date=6 August 2013|accessdate=22 June 2015|publisher=Parma F.C.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714174727/http://fcparma.com/flashnews/shirt-numbers-2013-14?lang=en|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Sampdoria=== On 31 January 2014, Okaka was transferred to the fellow Serie A outfit [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]] on a permanent deal, with [[Nicola Pozzi]] moving the opposite direction.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sampdoria.it/okaka-e-un-calciatore-blucerchiato-pozzi-va-al-parma.html|title=Okaka è un calciatore blucerchiato, Pozzi va al Parma|date=31 January 2014|accessdate=9 February 2014|work=U.C. Sampdoria|language=Italian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202101632/http://www.sampdoria.it/okaka-e-un-calciatore-blucerchiato-pozzi-va-al-parma.html|archivedate=2 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He made a good start to his Sampdoria career, scoring five times in 13 appearances in the 2013–14 season.
He scored his first goal of the [[2014–15 Serie A|2014–15]] season on 14 September 2014, a solo effort, in the 2–0 victory against [[Torino F.C.|Torino]] on 14 September 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Grimaldi|first1=Filippo|title=Sampdoria-Torino 2–0: Gabbiadini e Okaka, show a Marassi|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/14-09-2014/sampdoria-torino-2-0-gabbiadini-okaka-show-marassi-90446992070.shtml#|accessdate=28 June 2016|work=La Gazetta dello Sport|date=14 September 2014|language=Italian}}</ref> On 10 June 2015, the owner and president of Sampdoria Massimo Ferrero told the Italian media that Okaka would be leaving the club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sampdoria, Ferrero: "No a Pazzini. Eder resta, Okaka via. Cassano? Vedremo..."|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calciomercato/10-06-2015/sampdoria-ferrero-no-pazzini-eder-resta-okaka-via-cassano-vedremo-120118923093.shtml#|accessdate=28 June 2016|work=La Gazzetta dello Sport|date=10 June 2015|language=Italian}}</ref>
===Anderlecht=== On 28 July 2015, Okaka joined Belgian side [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] from Sampdoria.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official: Anderlecht sign Okaka|url=http://www.football-italia.net/70216/official-anderlecht-sign-okaka|website=Football Italia|accessdate=10 April 2016|date=28 July 2015}}</ref>
===Watford=== On 29 August 2016, Okaka joined [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] from Anderlecht on a five-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official: Okaka signs|url=https://www.watfordfc.com/teams/first-team/okaka-signs|website=Watford FC|accessdate=30 April 2016|date=29 August 2016}}</ref> He scored his first two goals for Watford on 10 December 2016, against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in a Premier League match which Watford went on to win 3–2. Okaka first equalised for the ''Hornets'' to make it one apiece, producing an elegant [[Glossary of association football terms|back-heeled]] strike from inside the six-yard box and then put his side 3–1 up after heading in from a corner. He was awarded the 'man of the match' in that game.
===Udinese=== On 8 January 2019, Okaka was signed by [[Udinese Calcio|Udinese]] on a season long loan deal.<ref>https://www.football-italia.net/132984/official-okaka-joins-udinese</ref>
==International career== After gaining Italian citizenship in 2007, Okaka was selected for the [[Italy national under-19 football team|Italian Under-19]] side. He made his debut for the Italy U-20 team in 2008, scoring two goals.<ref name="figc_presenze">{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/nazionali/DettaglioConvocato?codiceConvocato=3155&squadra=3|publisher=FIGC.it|language=Italian|title= OKAPA CHUKA STEFANO – Convocazioni e presenze in campo|accessdate=9 September 2009}}</ref> On 17 November 2009, he made his debut with the [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy U-21]] squad in a match against [[Luxembourg national under-21 football team|Luxembourg]].
In April 2014, Okaka revealed he was in talks with the [[Nigeria Football Federation]] about the possibility of him switching allegiance to his parents' country and play with the [[Nigeria national football team]] already at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/24-04-2014/okaka-gioca-la-nigeria-ci-penso-ma-sono-italiano-80512356275.shtml |publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian |accessdate=25 April 2014 |date=24 April 2014 |title=Okaka gioca per la Nigeria? "Ci penso, ma sono italiano" |trans-title=Okaka playing for Nigeria? "I am thinking, but I am Italian" }}</ref>
However, Okaka was included in the Italy squad for their friendly against [[Albania national football team|Albania]] on 18 November 2014 by manager [[Antonio Conte]]. He made his debut as a substitute, replacing [[Sebastian Giovinco]] in the second half, and scored the winning goal at Sampdoria's ground the [[Stadio Luigi Ferraris]].<ref>{{cite news|title=International friendly: Italy edge to narrow 1–0 victory over Albania in Genoa|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/327826/report|accessdate=19 November 2014|work=[[Sky Sports]]|date=18 November 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== Okaka's twin sister, [[Stefania Okaka]], is also a professional sportsperson.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Geypen|first1=Diederik|title=Stefano Okaka maakt voorlopig het meeste indruk met tweelingzus Stefania|url=https://www.voetbalkrant.com/nl/nieuws/lees/2015-08-11/stefano-okaka-maakt-voorlopig-het-meeste-indruk-met-tweelingzus-stefania|website=voetbalkrant.com|accessdate=21 December 2015|date=11 August 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref> A volleyball player, she plays for [[Béziers Volley]] of the [[Ligue A|French first division]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lambaerts|first1=Geert|title=Tweelingzus van Okaka: "Stefano heeft in België zijn lach teruggevonden"|url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/1284/Anderlecht/article/detail/2500753/2015/10/24/Tweelingzus-van-Okaka-Stefano-heeft-in-Belgie-zijn-lach-teruggevonden.dhtml|accessdate=21 December 2015|work=[[Het Laatste Nieuws]]|date=24 October 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref> and the [[Italy women's national volleyball team|Italian national team]].
